component:ember-needs-async/components/n.title: NeedsAsync
component:ember-needs-async/components/n.text: Usage:  <NeedsAsync @needs=(find-record 'user' '1') as |States|> <States.loading> <!-- render a loading state here --> </States.loading> <States.loaded as |user|> <!-- render whatever needs 'user' here --> </States.loaded> <States.error as |error|> <!-- render an error state here optionally using 'error' --> </States.error> </NeedsAsync>

attributes.name: NeedsAsync
attributes.description:
Usage:

  <NeedsAsync @needs=(find-record 'user' '1') as |States|>
    <States.loading>
      <!-- render a loading state here -->
    </States.loading>
    <States.loaded as |user|>
      <!-- render whatever needs 'user' here -->
    </States.loaded>
    <States.error as |error|>
      <!-- render an error state here optionally using 'error' -->
    </States.error>
  </NeedsAsync>

yields.name: States.loading
yields.description: a component that renders its block if the task instance is still loading

yields.name: States.loaded
yields.description: a component that renders its block and yields the task value once the task is done loading

yields.name: States.error
yields.description: a component that renders its block and yields an error if the tak encountered an error

functions.name: async-all
functions.description:
Usage:

  {{async-all (array
    (find-record "user" "1")
    (find-record "user" "2")
  )}}

returns.description: a TaskInstance that resolves to an array of TaskInstance results

params.name: taskInstances
params.description: an array of Ember Concurrency task instances

functions.name: async-hash
functions.description:
Usage:

  {{async-hash (hash
    foo=(find-record "user" "1")
    bar=(find-record "user" "2")
  )}}

returns.description: a TaskInstance that resolves to a hash of TaskInstance results

params.name: taskInstances
params.description: an array of Ember Concurrency task instances

functions.name: belongs-to
functions.description:
Usage:

  {{belongs-to user "company"}}

returns.description: a TaskInstance that resolves to a DS.Model

params.name: model
params.description: the model to fetch the belongs-to relationship from

params.name: relationship
params.description: the name of the relationship to fetch

functions.name: find-all
functions.description:
Usage:

  {{find-all "user" (hash include="company")}}

returns.description: a TaskInstance that resolves to a DS.RecordArray

params.name: options
params.description: (optional) options to pass to the store.findAll method

functions.name: find-all
functions.description:
Usage:

  {{find-record "user" "1" (hash include="company")}}

returns.description: a promise that resolves to a DS.Model

params.name: id
params.description: the id of the model to request

params.name: options
params.description: (optional) options to pass to the store.findRecord method

functions.name: has-many
functions.description:
Usage:

  {{has-many company "employees"}}

returns.description: a TaskInstance that resolves to a DS.RecordArray

params.name: model
params.description: the model to fetch the has-many relationship from

params.name: relationship
params.description: the name of the relationship to fetch

functions.name: peek-all
functions.description:
Usage:

  {{peek-all "user"}}

returns.description: a TaskInstance that resolves immediately to a DS.RecordArray

functions.name: peek-record
functions.description:
Usage:

  {{peek-record "user" "1"}}

returns.description: a TaskInstance that resolves immediately to a DS.Model

params.name: id
params.description: the id of the model to fetch from the store

functions.name: query
functions.description:
Usage:

  {{query "user" (hash lastName="smith" page=2)}}

returns.description: a TaskInstance that resolves to a DS.RecordArray

params.name: query
params.description: the hash that includes all params for the query

template:docs/async-all.title: async-all helper
template:docs/async-all.text: async-all helper The async-all helper takes an array of tasks and yields a task that finishes when all of the subtasks finish. It is exactly the same as the ember-concurrency all task. Three Users Loading users...

template:docs/async-hash.title: async-hash helper
template:docs/async-hash.text: async-hash helper The async-hash helper takes a hash of tasks and yields a task that finishes when all of the subtasks finish. It is exactly the same as the ember-concurrency hash task. Three users with labels Loading... :

template:docs/belongs-to.title: belongs-to
template:docs/belongs-to.text: belongs-to The belongs-to helper takes a model and a relationship name and returns an ember concurrency task that resolves to the value of the relationship once loaded. User Company Details LOADING USER LOADING COMPANY DATA -

template:docs/find-all.title: find-all helper
template:docs/find-all.text: find-all helper The find-all helper takes a model type and returns an ember concurrency task which will resolve to an array of models. It is the same as store.findAll(). All Users Loading users...

template:docs/find-record.title: find-record helper
template:docs/find-record.text: find-record helper The find-record helper takes a model type and an id and returns an ember concurrency task that resolves to a record. It is exactly the same as store.findRecord(). One User Loading user...

template:docs/has-many.title: has-many
template:docs/has-many.text: has-many The has-many helper takes a model and a relationship name and returns an ember concurrency task that resolves to the value of the relationship once loaded. Company Employees LOADING COMPANY LOADING USERS

template:docs/index.title: Introduction
template:docs/index.text: Introduction ember-needs-async is a little experiment into the idea of loading data in templates. It's very lightweight and consists of just a couple simple parts: a needs-async provider component which takes a "need" (technically an ember concurrency task instance) and yields "state" provider components such as "loading", "loaded" and "error" a few helpers which correspond to common Ember Data operations such as find-record, has-many, etc. These pieces together allow declarative asynchronous data fetching and rendering using only a handlebars template. While there are undoubtedly very valid criticisms of this approach and particularly this implementation, there are probably also some valid use cases for loading data in this manner. It's also fun to play around with. Check out usage for the basics on how to use the addon or head over to examples to see some samples and ideas.

template:docs/needs-async.title: needs-async component
template:docs/needs-async.text: needs-async component The needs-async component is a tagless (renders nothing in the DOM) provider component that accepts an ember concurrency task instance as an argument (called @needs) and yields three "states" (loading, loaded, error) that render their blocks based on the state of the "needs" task. It also yields the taskInstance. The "loaded" state will yield the value of the task, the "error" state will yield any errors, and the "loading" state yields nothing. While this component is intended to be used with the helpers provided by this addon it can also be used with any ember-concurrency task instance, as demonstrated in the example below. Click for random number: loading...

template:docs/peek-all.title: peek-all helper
template:docs/peek-all.text: peek-all helper The peek-all helper takes a model type and returns an ember concurrency task which will resolve to an array of models. It is the same as store.peekAll(). (Hint: if no users show up try navigating to the find-all helper and then back.) All Users Loading users...

template:docs/peek-record.title: peek-record helper
template:docs/peek-record.text: peek-record helper The peek-record helper takes a model type and an id and returns an ember concurrency task that resolves to a record. It is exactly the same as store.peekRecord(). (Hint: if no record appears try navigating to the find-record helper) One User Loading user...

template:docs/usage.title: Usage
template:docs/usage.text: Usage This is an example of a needs-async component that loads a specific user, and once the user is loaded another needs-async that loads the "company" relationship for the user and displays the data. LOADING USER DATA , LOADING COMPANY DATA - ERROR STATE: That's really all there is to it. The needs-async component takes an ember concurrency task (which all of the included helpers provide) and yields state components for rendering different data based on loading state, loaded state, and error state.

template:index.title: A simple example
template:index.text: A simple example Here is a simple example that loads a user record from the "backend" using the provided id and displays the name and avatar once it is loaded. Type a user id in the input above Loading user data... There was a problem loading user with id
